Gardener, Esq., C.B.E., Establishment and Organisation Department, The Foreign Office, London, B.W.1.1 56/21 Aa 'ow. fc.tr British Embassy, Tehran. 22 nd July, 1948 % I have asked the Foreign Office whether we may \\ jnlist your help with the Pakistan G-overnment in the following matter which concerns the accounts of the Zahidan Consulate. In a recent despatch Gastrell, our Consul-General at ivieshed, has asked to be relieved of financial responsibility for Zahidan. I may explain that until 13th August 1947 the annual budget and monthly accounts of the Zahidan Consulate ’were regularly checked in the office of the Consul-General, Meshed, and forwarded by them to External Affairs Department and the Accountant General Central Revenues at New Delhi. Since that date Pakistan have been paying for the Consulate as a temporary measure, and Meshed have been sending the accounts to Karachi. Gastrell points out that whereas in the old days the Consul-General at Meshed had several Indian clerks, including a trained accountant, on his staff, now he has lost his accountant and after 15 th August next will have no clerks at all with experience of India and the Indian accounting system. He will therefore not be in a position to supervise the accounts of the Zahidan Consulate, and he suggests that in future they should be supervised either by the Pakistan Embassy here or by the Accountant General, Central Revenues of Pakistan** We have asked the Pakistan Chargd d* Affaires what he thinks about it and whether he would be willing to undertake the responsibility in question. He is definitely unwilling to do so* Whan Pakistan establish their own Consulates, he says, they will doubtless be placed under the charge of the Pakistan Embassy, the staff of which will be strengthened for the purpose. Until this happens he requests us to arrange with the Pakistan Government for the Zahidan accounts to be super vised by their Accountant General in direct correspondence with the Consul. This seems to me to be the most suitable arrangement, and I hope that the Foreign Office will shortly move the Commonwealth Relations Office to send you instructions in this sense. I shall be very grateful to know as soon as possible whether the Government of Pakistan agree. (Sgd.) M.J. CxtH^.ELL. Sir L.B. U.K. Grafftey-Smith, K.C.M.G., High Commissioner, KAR^Chi

titleInfo.title: Pol Ext 16872/48 'Accounts of Zahidan Consulate: Supervision Arrangements'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 8; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence regarding a request for oversight of the accounts of the British Consulate at Zahidan (Zahedan), Iran to be transferred to the Government of Pakistan. The correspondents are: British Legation, Tehran; Foreign Office; Commonwealth Relations Office.
